abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the HIV/AIDS and STDs
            Prevention and Management Project was rated as
            unsatisfactory. The project was successful in developing a
            laboratory system to support HIV/AIDS and STD testing and
            surveillance, unfortunately support from the other
            components was negligible. As a result, the project was not
            able to produce a comprehensive model of proved
            effectiveness for the prevention and management of HIV/AIDS
            and STDs. Bank supervision was ineffective in pushing
            attainment of project goals. Key lessons drawn this project
            include: 1) the project was ambitious in its design and
            objectives. Three years was too short a period for achieving
            behavioral change targets, particularly since most
            guidelines, manuals, modules, and information, education,
            and communication materials materials were still to be
            developed during the first years of the project. 2) The
            decision to establish a Project Management Unit (PMU) led by
            a Project Manager who was responsible not just for project
            administration but also for technical matters proved to be
            counter productive. 3) The project was a pilot that had to
            deal with numerous activities in a short time frame,
            involving multiple groups of people, numerous agencies and
            individuals in different locations. 4) The project correctly
            put an nongovernmental organizations capacity building
            component in the project, which was directed particularly at
            smaller nongovernmental organizations with strong ties to
            particular groups of interest.
